awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Arithmetic Geometry Methods in  Complexity and Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
Security and efficiency remain central problems in cryptology and communication. Over the centuries, cryptography has advanced, from ad hoc secret codes that can be broken by hand, to methods based on number theory which remain secure even against adversaries using super-computers.  As algorithms from number theory have advanced, our codes for protecting data have also progressed in efficiency: NASA regularly transmits clear pictures of terrain on faraway planets, using error-correcting codes that cut through the noise of solar flares, cell phones, and radio transmissions. As our communication methods have evolved, we are naturally led to deep mathematical problems which must be solved before we can make further progress. Some of these problems are also deeply connected to central questions in complexity theory and new advances in optimization.

The investigators will focus on advanced techniques toward tackling central problems in circuit complexity and pseudo-randomness. In particular, they will apply recent advances in arithmetic geometry to the construction of new pseudo-random generators and new complexity lower bounds. One technique the investigators will pursue is their recent discovery of an efficient method to count solutions of polynomial equations over finite rings. This technique will help analyze a new family of pseudo-random generators with potentially better unpredictability than earlier constructions based on discrete logarithms and factoring. The research team will also use techniques from real and p-adic geometry to study the number of integer solutions to structured polynomials. The latter problem is one of the few recent methods with the potential to yield new lower bounds for circuit complexity and a better understanding of the P vs. NP question. In addition to this algorithmic research, the investigators will train graduate students, and use all work from this project to develop new content for courses and outreach programs for younger students. The investigators are committed to broadening the participation of under-represented groups in computing and ensuring new talent from all sources is available for future research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a natural belief that ``simple'' equations should have ``simple''
solutions. This belief is actually (provably) true in some settings, like the
study of real solutions of polynomial equations: The resulting body of
theorems is called (real) fewnomial theory.

However, there are other settings where it is hard to prove that solutions
to ``simple'' equations have to be simple or few in number. In fact, thanks
to recent work in theoretical computer science, there is an explanation:
A (solid mathematical) proof that certain structured equations have few
solutions would imply the resolution of decades-old questions close to the
P vs. NP Problem! This is exciting, because the P vs. NP Problem has tremendous
broader impact: If P=NP then many hard problems related to aritifical
intelligence (AI) would be solvable much more efficiently than
previously thought, thus eventually resulting in improved AI. If P is
not equal to NP, then one would be able to rigorously prove many of the ad hoc
assumptions currently used in information security, thus eventually resulting
in (provably) unbreakably secure communications.

This project focusses on the study of systems of equations that are
simple in the sense that they are easy to write down --- equations that are
sums of few monomial terms --- and closely studies their number of solutions
and the hardness of finding these solutions. The concern with hardness of
finding solutions is not just practical: Understanding what kinds of equations
are hard to solve helps yield new cryptographic protocols that are useful
for securing private information. A key intellectual strength of this work
is the breadth of solutions we consider: Our techniques apply to real number
solutions, solutions over finite fields, as well as solutions over the
p-adic rational numbers. Each of these three settings sheds new light on a
particular aspect of arithmetic geometry underlying this work.

The outcomes of our work include introducing undergraduates to their
first research experiences, training graduate students to become
successful mathematicians, shaping the direction of future research
through active participation in conferences, and publishing in major
research journals. (Rojas is also PI on an REU at Texas A&M, where he mentors
numerous undergrads, many from under-represented groups.) A full technical
description of our work can be found easily within the research papers freely
downloadable from the principal investigators' web pages.

One highlight of this work is a new, polynomial-time algorithm for counting
the number of real solutions of certain systems of polynomial equations
in many variables. The best previous algorithms took exponential time.
A key new ingredient was our combination of results from diophantine
approximation and real algebraic geometry --- two areas that were
seemingly totally unconnected before our work.
